body: If you add a single non-ignored thing on the middle device, does that change the situation?

Not really. The newly added file does get synced from B to C, but the rest looks exactly the same as before.

The number of Out of Sync Items is also strange. It seems that it includes files that existed in the past, and were ignored at that time, but are long gone now. Currently the only files that exist are 50 files on Device A (plus the 1 file created on B for testing purposes right now). The other 450 files listed below were deleted previously and are no longer present.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5626656/111060675-0073da80-84e2-11eb-9251-c07c3298531d.png)
Yeah, although the number is likely because I reused my test folder. Normally, there should be just the currently existing 50 files stuck in sync.

This is https://forum.syncthing.net/t/folder-stuck-in-sync-and-non-matching-local-and-global-states/16431/14, right?

The reason is that we have an "efficiency" measure: We do not pull items that are not present at all locally and globally invalid or deleted. B sees valid items from A, thus their global is valid. C only sees invalid items from B, thus their global is invalid and they don't pull. B doesn't know about C's global, thus shows C as out of sync. The fix here is to always pull invalid files ("pull" as in create a local invalid entry too).
Alternately we could just document that this happens and say not to do it.

> Alternately we could just document that this happens and say not to do it.

What should be done in this situation though?

The only workaround that I can think of would be to connect Device A with Device C directly, which in this particular case I cannot do, as Device A is someone else's machine, outside of my control.

I have also tried using the same ignore patterns on Device C, but it doesn't change anything either.

**Edit**: I just wanted to say thank you very much @imsodin for such a quick fix! ðŸ™‚

issue.body:
### Purpose

Scenario (https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/issues/7474#issuecomment-798881296):

> The reason is that we have an "efficiency" measure: We do not pull items that are not present at all locally and globally invalid or deleted. B sees valid items from A, thus their global is valid. C only sees invalid items from B, thus their global is invalid and they don't pull. B doesn't know about C's global, thus shows C as out of sync. The fix here is to always pull invalid files ("pull" as in create a local invalid entry too).

I adjusted `Need` to consider invalid files needed, and added a shortcut to the puller to send invalid files directly to the db. If at some point we do create a local file, that "trumps" the invalid file as usual (bumps the version of the invalid file, uninvalidates it, ...).

I also added a db migration to trigger a repair, otherwise the changes don't take effect.

### Testing

Unit test checking that we do pull and send back an invalid file info.  
Needed to add some machinery to the fake connection to correctly send invalid files.

issue.body:
Came up in https://forum.syncthing.net/t/syncthing-lost-one-file-out-of-a-dozen-on-one-node/16721.

Reproducer:

Initial State: Devices A, B share a folder. A has file F, B ignores file F.

1. Connect additional device C to B, wait for index exchange and sync/pull to finish.
2. Connect C to A.

Expected: File F gets synced to C.

Result: File F does not get synced to C.

This is a regression introduced in https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/pull/7476, which in turn fixes https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/issues/7474.

Unfortunately the solution for #7474 implemented in #7476 created a new, more severe problem: Files that should be synced, aren't: #7608. I couldn't come up with a way to fix #7474 without introducing this regression that doesn't add a lot of complexity. Thus I reverted that change and thus re-introduce #7474. As that is only a "presentation issue" that's clearly the more desirable issue to have.

Most of the diff here is due to the migration needed to resolve issues for users already affected by #7608. As I needed a file info batch in this migration, I moved the `fileInfoBatch` from model to db.

### Testing

I introduced a new unit test reproducing #7608 and removed the test for #7474.
